title: Deploying Shiny App to GitHub Pages & Quarto
text:
This guide covers two deployment methods for your Penguin Data Analysis app.





Run in R terminal:
library(shinylive)

# Export your app
shinylive::export(
  appdir = "deploy_app",
  destdir = "docs"
)
This creates a docs/ folder with static HTML/JS files.



cd /home/kiennm/Cancer_Epigenetics_Study

# Initialize git
git init

# Add files
git add .gitignore
git add docs/
git add deploy_app/
git add README.md

# Commit
git commit -m "Initial commit: Penguin Shiny app with Shinylive"




Go to https://github.com/new
Create a new repository (e.g., ‚Äúpenguin-analysis‚Äù)
Don‚Äôt initialize with README (we already have files)




# Add remote (replace with your username)
git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/penguin-analysis.git

# Push
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main




Go to your repo on GitHub
Click Settings ‚Üí Pages
Under Source, select:

Branch: main
Folder: /docs

Click Save

Your app will be live at: https://YOUR_USERNAME.github.io/penguin-analysis/







Download from: https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/
Or on Ubuntu:
sudo apt install quarto



cd /home/kiennm/Cancer_Epigenetics_Study
quarto add quarto-ext/shinylive



The penguins-app.qmd file is already created. Render it:
quarto render penguins-app.qmd
This creates penguins-app.html with the embedded Shinylive app!



Create _quarto.yml:
project:
  type: website
  output-dir: docs

website:
  title: "Cancer Epigenetics Study"
  navbar:
    left:
      - href: index.qmd
        text: Home
      - href: penguins-app.qmd
        text: Penguin Analysis
      - href: about.qmd
        text: About

format:
  html:
    theme: cosmo
    css: styles.css
    toc: true

filters:
  - shinylive
Create index.qmd:
---
title: "Cancer Epigenetics Study"
---

## Welcome

This website contains interactive data analysis tools for cancer epigenetics research.

### Apps

- [Penguin Data Explorer](penguins-app.html) - Interactive visualization tool
Render entire site:
quarto render
Preview locally:
quarto preview



# After rendering (creates docs/ folder)
git add .
git commit -m "Add Quarto website with Shinylive apps"
git push

# Enable GitHub Pages (Settings ‚Üí Pages ‚Üí source: main ‚Üí /docs)







library(shinylive)
shinylive::export("deploy_app", "docs")



quarto render penguins-app.qmd



quarto preview



git add .
git commit -m "Update app"
git push







quarto add quarto-ext/shinylive --no-prompt




Check that docs/ folder is committed
Verify GitHub Pages settings point to /docs
Wait 2-3 minutes for deployment
Check browser console for errors





Ensure you have the filters: - shinylive in YAML header
Use {shinylive-r} not {r}
Install shinylive extension: quarto add quarto-ext/shinylive






Cancer_Epigenetics_Study/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .gitignore
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ DEPLOYMENT.md              # This file
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ deploy_app/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ app.R                  # Original Shiny app
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/                      # Generated by shinylive export
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.html
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ shinylive/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ...
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ penguins-app.qmd          # Quarto doc with embedded app
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ penguins-app.html         # Rendered output
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ _quarto.yml               # Optional: website config





Export your app: Run the R command above
Initialize git: Run the bash commands
Create GitHub repo: Follow Step 3
Push and enable Pages: Follow Steps 4-5
Share your URL: https://YOUR_USERNAME.github.io/penguin-analysis/






Shinylive Documentation
Quarto Shinylive Extension
GitHub Pages Guide
Quarto Websites

title: Welcome to Cancer Epigenetics Study
text: This website contains interactive data analysis tools and visualizations for cancer epigenetics research.

title: Welcome to Cancer Epigenetics Study
text: This website contains interactive data analysis tools and visualizations for cancer epigenetics research.

title: Welcome to Cancer Epigenetics Study
text:
Interactive Applications

Penguin Data Explorer
An interactive Shiny application for exploring the Palmer Penguins dataset. This demonstrates:

Interactive data visualization
Dynamic user inputs
Real-time plot updates
Shinylive browser-based deployment

Features: - Select X and Y axis variables - Color data by species, sex, or island - Runs entirely in your browser (no server required!)

title: Welcome to Cancer Epigenetics Study
text:
Getting Started
Click on Penguin Analysis in the navigation bar to start exploring the data.

title: Welcome to Cancer Epigenetics Study
text:
Technology Stack
This site is built with:

R: Statistical computing
Shiny: Interactive web applications
Shinylive: Browser-based Shiny apps
Quarto: Scientific publishing system
ggplot2: Data visualization
GitHub Pages: Free hosting

title: Welcome to Cancer Epigenetics Study
text:
About the Project
This project demonstrates modern approaches to creating and deploying interactive data analysis applications for scientific research.

title: Penguin Data Analysis with Shinylive
text:
This interactive application allows you to explore the Palmer Penguins dataset. You can select different variables for the X and Y axes, and color the points by species, sex, or island.


#| '!! shinylive warning !!': |
#|   shinylive does not work in self-contained HTML documents.
#|   Please set `embed-resources: false` in your metadata.
#| standalone: true
#| viewerHeight: 600

# Loading required libraries
library(shiny)
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)

# Create Input() UI 
ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Penguin Data Analysis"),
  
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      selectInput("xvar", "X-axis variable:",
                  choices = c("Flipper Length" = "flipper_length_mm",
                              "Bill Length" = "bill_length_mm",
                              "Bill Depth" = "bill_depth_mm",
                              "Body Mass" = "body_mass_g")),
      selectInput("yvar", "Y-axis variable:",
                  choices = c("Body Mass" = "body_mass_g",
                              "Flipper Length" = "flipper_length_mm",
                              "Bill Length" = "bill_length_mm",
                              "Bill Depth" = "bill_depth_mm")),
      selectInput("colorvar", "Color by:",
                  choices = c("Species" = "species",
                              "Sex" = "sex",
                              "Island" = "island"))
    ),
    
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("scatterPlot")
    )
  )
)

# Server determine how to render outputs given inputs
server <- function(input, output) {
  
  output$scatterPlot <- renderPlot({
    ggplot(data = penguins, aes_string(x = input$xvar, y = input$yvar, color = input$colorvar)) +
      geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
      labs(title = paste(input$yvar, "vs", input$xvar),
           x = input$xvar,
           y = input$yvar) +
      theme_minimal() +
      theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"))
  })  
}

shinyApp(ui, server)

title: Penguin Data Analysis with Shinylive
text:
This interactive application allows you to explore the Palmer Penguins dataset. You can select different variables for the X and Y axes, and color the points by species, sex, or island.


#| '!! shinylive warning !!': |
#|   shinylive does not work in self-contained HTML documents.
#|   Please set `embed-resources: false` in your metadata.
#| standalone: true
#| viewerHeight: 600

# Loading required libraries
library(shiny)
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)

# Create Input() UI 
ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Penguin Data Analysis"),
  
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      selectInput("xvar", "X-axis variable:",
                  choices = c("Flipper Length" = "flipper_length_mm",
                              "Bill Length" = "bill_length_mm",
                              "Bill Depth" = "bill_depth_mm",
                              "Body Mass" = "body_mass_g")),
      selectInput("yvar", "Y-axis variable:",
                  choices = c("Body Mass" = "body_mass_g",
                              "Flipper Length" = "flipper_length_mm",
                              "Bill Length" = "bill_length_mm",
                              "Bill Depth" = "bill_depth_mm")),
      selectInput("colorvar", "Color by:",
                  choices = c("Species" = "species",
                              "Sex" = "sex",
                              "Island" = "island"))
    ),
    
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("scatterPlot")
    )
  )
)

# Server determine how to render outputs given inputs
server <- function(input, output) {
  
  output$scatterPlot <- renderPlot({
    ggplot(data = penguins, aes_string(x = input$xvar, y = input$yvar, color = input$colorvar)) +
      geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
      labs(title = paste(input$yvar, "vs", input$xvar),
           x = input$xvar,
           y = input$yvar) +
      theme_minimal() +
      theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"))
  })  
}

shinyApp(ui, server)

title: Penguin Data Analysis with Shinylive
text:
About the Data
The Palmer Penguins dataset contains size measurements for three penguin species observed on three islands in the Palmer Archipelago, Antarctica.
Variables: - Species: Adelie, Chinstrap, or Gentoo - Island: Biscoe, Dream, or Torgersen - Bill Length (mm): Length of the bill - Bill Depth (mm): Depth of the bill - Flipper Length (mm): Length of the flipper - Body Mass (g): Body mass

title: Penguin Data Analysis with Shinylive
text:
How to Use This App

Select the variable you want on the X-axis
Select the variable you want on the Y-axis
Choose a grouping variable for colors (species, sex, or island)
The plot updates automatically!

title: Penguin Data Analysis with Shinylive
text:
Learn More

Palmer Penguins R Package
Shinylive Documentation
Quarto Documentation

title: Quick Start: Deploy Your Penguin App
text:
I‚Äôve set up everything you need! Here are the two deployment methods:





# Check if installed
quarto --version

# If not installed, download from:
# https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/
# Or on Ubuntu:
sudo apt install quarto



cd /home/kiennm/Cancer_Epigenetics_Study
./deploy.sh
This script will: - ‚úÖ Install Quarto Shinylive extension - ‚úÖ Build your website to docs/ folder - ‚úÖ Initialize git and commit files - ‚úÖ Show you next steps



Create a new repo at: https://github.com/new
Then run (replace YOUR_USERNAME):
git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/penguin-analysis.git
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main




Go to your repo ‚Üí Settings ‚Üí Pages
Source: main branch
Folder: /docs
Click Save

Done! Visit: https://YOUR_USERNAME.github.io/penguin-analysis/





If you want more control:


cd /home/kiennm/Cancer_Epigenetics_Study
quarto add quarto-ext/shinylive --no-prompt



# Just the app page
quarto render penguins-app.qmd

# Preview it
quarto preview penguins-app.qmd



# Build full site
quarto render

# Preview locally
quarto preview
The app will open in your browser at http://localhost:XXXX








‚úÖ penguins-app.qmd - Quarto doc with embedded Shinylive app
‚úÖ _quarto.yml - Website configuration
‚úÖ index.qmd - Home page
‚úÖ about.qmd - About page





‚úÖ DEPLOYMENT.md - Detailed deployment guide
‚úÖ QUICKSTART.md - This file
‚úÖ deploy.sh - Automated deployment script





‚úÖ .gitignore - Git ignore rules






A complete Quarto website with:
üì± Home Page (index.qmd) - Overview of your project - Links to apps
üêß Interactive App (penguins-app.qmd) - Embedded Shinylive Shiny app - Runs in browser (no server!) - Data exploration tools
‚ÑπÔ∏è About Page (about.qmd) - Project information - Technology stack - Dataset details






cd /home/kiennm/Cancer_Epigenetics_Study

# Start preview server
quarto preview

# Opens at: http://localhost:XXXX
# Auto-reloads when you edit files



# Render and open
quarto render penguins-app.qmd
xdg-open penguins-app.html







Edit _quarto.yml:
format:
  html:
    theme: flatly  # Try: cosmo, flatly, minty, pulse, etc.




Create new .qmd file
Add to _quarto.yml navbar
Run quarto render




In any .qmd file:
```{shinylive-r}
#| standalone: true

library(shiny)
# Your Shiny app code here...
```







Install from: https://quarto.org/



quarto add quarto-ext/shinylive --no-prompt



Check you have:
filters:
  - shinylive
In your _quarto.yml or document YAML header.




Wait 2-3 minutes after pushing
Check Settings ‚Üí Pages shows ‚ÄúYour site is published‚Äù
Verify /docs folder is committed
Check browser console for errors







Run the deployment script: ./deploy.sh
Create GitHub repo: https://github.com/new
Push your code: Follow the script‚Äôs instructions
Enable Pages: Settings ‚Üí Pages ‚Üí /docs folder
Share your app! üéâ





Check these files: - DEPLOYMENT.md - Detailed guide - README.md - Project overview - Quarto docs: https://quarto.org/docs/websites/

You‚Äôre all set! Run ./deploy.sh to get started! üöÄ

title: About
text: This Cancer Epigenetics Study website showcases interactive data analysis tools built with R, Shiny, and modern web technologies.

title: About
text: This Cancer Epigenetics Study website showcases interactive data analysis tools built with R, Shiny, and modern web technologies.

title: About
text:
Purpose
The goal is to demonstrate:

Reproducible Research: Using R and Quarto for transparent analysis
Interactive Visualization: Creating engaging data exploration tools
Modern Deployment: Leveraging Shinylive for browser-based apps
Open Science: Sharing tools freely via GitHub Pages

title: About
text:
Technology

R and Shiny

R: Statistical programming language
Shiny: Framework for interactive web apps
ggplot2: Grammar of graphics for elegant visualizations



Shinylive
Shinylive allows Shiny apps to run entirely in the browser using WebAssembly. This means: - No R server required - Free hosting on GitHub Pages - Instant loading (after initial assets) - Works offline after first load


Quarto
Quarto is a scientific publishing system that: - Combines narrative text with code - Renders to websites, PDFs, presentations - Supports multiple languages (R, Python, Julia) - Integrates with Shinylive for embedded apps

title: About
text:
Dataset
The Palmer Penguins dataset was collected and made available by Dr.¬†Kristen Gorman and the Palmer Station, Antarctica LTER. It‚Äôs an excellent alternative to the classic Iris dataset for data science education.
Citation: Horst AM, Hill AP, Gorman KB (2020). palmerpenguins: Palmer Archipelago (Antarctica) penguin data. R package version 0.1.0. https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/

title: About
text:
Contact
For questions or collaboration: - GitHub: [Your GitHub Profile] - Email: [Your Email]

title: About
text:
License
Code: MIT License Content: CC BY 4.0

Built with ‚ù§Ô∏è using R, Shiny, and Quarto
